posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked:
Hey folks!

It‚Äôs been a while since all of Signal‚Äôs clients started uploading compressed files to debuglogs.org. While it‚Äôs let us upload more useful logs, I know it‚Äôs also been a pain for people who submit them and would like to look through them, since it forces you to download them and unzip them manually.

To help alleviate that, I made a webapp called debuglogs.app. The way it works is that if you take any debuglogs.org link and replace .org with .app, you‚Äôll see a nice in-browser viewer with some cool features.

The server is little more than a proxy ‚Äì all the actual logic (including unzipping and reconfiguring iOS logs) is done in the client. So apologies if it‚Äôs a little slow to render on older machines :)

It‚Äôs open source and AGPL-licensed. You can see the code here:

GitHub

GitHub - greysonp/debuglogs.app: An in-browser viewer for debuglogs.org

An in-browser viewer for debuglogs.org. Contribute to greysonp/debuglogs.app development by creating an account on GitHub.

You‚Äôll notice that the repository is hosted on my personal Github. That‚Äôs because this is just a thing I did on my own, and I don‚Äôt want to set any expectations that this will be actively maintained or anything. That said, please feel free to report any bugs, and I‚Äôll see what I can do ;)

Enjoy!

Update 10/16
I wasn‚Äôt aware that a community member had made something similar! Please check out readlogs.pages.dev.

Also, to make it easier to use debuglogs.app, I created a small extension that will auto-redirect debuglogs.org ‚Üí debuglogs.app. The extensions are in review on the Chrome/Firefox stores, but in the meantime you can install from source here:

GitHub

GitHub - greysonp/debuglogs.app-extension: A browser extension to...

A browser extension to automatically redirect debulogs.org to debuglogs.app - GitHub - greysonp/debuglogs.app-extension: A browser extension to automatically redirect debulogs.org to debuglogs.app

(I also added the ability to download the original log on debuglogs.app, since that‚Äôll be hard with the extension )

Update 10/17
Live on the Firefox Add-on store.

Update 10/18
Live on the Chrome Web store.

Just to mention that there is a similar project over here:

github.com

GitHub - awaitlink/readlogs: An unofficial web app for viewing Signal debug...

An unofficial web app for viewing Signal debug logs without manually downloading or unarchiving them

It‚Äôs hosted on readlogs.pages.dev

We might want to merge the discussion with

Web app for viewing debug logs without manually downloading/unarchiving Off Topic
I‚Äôve made a (for now, quite simple) web app for viewing Signal debug logs. Please note that it is unofficial: it is not affilated with the Signal Technology Foundation or Signal Messenger, LLC. It‚Äôs available at readlogs.pages.dev; for details about how it works and suggestions or bug reports, visit the GitHub repository.

posts.cooked:
Great minds think alike I assume

By the way, I was asking @awaitlink about ways to hide my log links ‚Ä¶

And he said at one point that perhaps the best approach would be for Signal to have a selectable option that makes your debug log link only accessible by the relevant people (devs)

so you can post it publicly but know that it will only be viewed by the devs‚Ä¶

I know this is a tangent, but seeing you adding functionality for debuglogs reminded me of @awaitlink‚Äôs idea, so‚Ä¶ maybe bare it in mind

posts.name: link ‚ú¶
posts.cooked:
To compare the currently implemented features, the main difference between debuglogs.app and readlogs seems to be:

  • debuglogs.app does simpler parsing and just highlights the messages in a web-based editor according to their log level (which doesn‚Äôt account for multi-line log messages though). Though it also does some additional things like aligning the Android log.

    readlogs is perhaps more ‚Äúover-engineered‚Äù‚Äîit does strict parsing of the whole log and especially information sections (in order to show both the log and information in the form of tables). The parsing needs to be changed sometimes if a new section is added with a different formatting, otherwise you can only view the raw log text without any highlighting.

Other differences include:

  • I like the way debuglogs.app collapses sections (and merges the iOS log files), it‚Äôs definitely easier to see the context around a certain log message this way.

    readlogs allows to easily see just the messages of a certain log level and above (I can often just scroll to the very end and see the relevant error, as by default it only shows errors), but it‚Äôs hard to see the context around them.

  • In readlogs, you can just paste the debuglogs.org URL, rather than needing to replace .org with .app. I think readlogs‚Äô implementation may be easier to use on mobile, so this may be a useful feature to implement for debuglogs.app‚Äôs homepage.

    readlogs doesn‚Äôt currently support any kind of navigation (such as via the URL) though.

    It‚Äôs slightly concerning that debuglogs.app has the log information in the URL path (rather than the fragment, for example), which gets sent to the server. Although, considering that it‚Äôs later fetched via a proxy server anyway, that‚Äôs probably not a big issue.

  • I‚Äôm not sure whether debuglogs.app caches debuglogs‚Äô response‚Äîit seems like it doesn‚Äôt.

    readlogs partially does (it‚Äôs explained in more detail here), which combined with the previous point may also help privacy a bit if you open the same log multiple times, as it shouldn‚Äôt need to fetch any log-specific information from the server in that case at all (and also reduces server load, though that may also be unnecessary at this scale).

  • readlogs is implemented in Rust/WASM entirely (apart from the proxy server / worker in JS) using Yew; I haven‚Äôt (yet) made things like parsing asynchronous / parallel so that the UI doesn‚Äôt freeze while the app parses the log. In general, it seems to work slower than debuglogs.app.

  • Monaco in debuglogs.app provides a search with more features than readlogs‚Äô simple implementation. It also supports other keyboard shortcuts, features via F1, etc.

  • There are multiple themes in debuglogs.app, rather than just light or dark (based on the system theme) in readlogs.

link_counts.title: GitHub - u32i64/readlogs: An unofficial web app for viewing Signal debug logs without manually downloading or unarchiving them
